[[Duncan, Mississippi|Duncan]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|1953|8|19|1906|11|4|mf=y}}
[[Jackson, Mississippi|Jackson]], Mississippi, United States | instrument = [[Piano]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Delta blues]], [[boogie-woogie]], [[rhythm and blues]] | occupation = [[Pianist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = Early 1940s–1953 | label = [[Trumpet Records|Trumpet]] | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Willie Love''' (November 4, 1906 – August 19, 1953){{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1950.html |title=The 50s and earlier |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-02-01}} was an [[United States|American]] [[Delta blues]] [[pianist]]. He is best known for his association with, and accompaniment of [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]]. ==Biography== Love was born in [[Duncan, Mississippi|Duncan]], [[Mississippi]], and in 1942, he met [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]] in [[Greenville, Mississippi]]. They played regularly together at [[juke joint]]s throughout the [[Mississippi Delta]]. Love was influenced by the piano playing of [[Leroy Carr]], and adept at both standard blues and [[boogie-woogie]] styling. In 1947 [[Charley Booker]] moved to Greenville, where he worked with Love.Harris, S (1981): ''Blues Who's Who''. New York: Da Capo Press, p. 59 Two years later, [[Oliver Sain]] also relocated to Greenville to join his stepfather, Love, as the drummer in a band fronted by Williamson. When Williamson recorded for [[Trumpet Records]] in March 1951, Love played the piano on the [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]]. Trumpet's owner, Lillian McMurray, had Love return the following month, and again in July 1951, when Love recorded his best known number, the self-penned, "Everybody's Fishing." Love played piano and sang, while the accompanying guitar come from [[Elmore James]] and [[Joe Willie Wilkins]]. His backing band was known as the Three Aces. A further studio session in December 1951 had Love backed by [[Little Milton]] (guitar), T.J. Green (fiddle), and Junior Blackman (drums). In his [[adolescence|teenage]] years, [[Eddie Shaw]] played [[tenor saxophone]] with both Milton and Love.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | pages= 165–166 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} Under his own name, Love did not return to the studio until March 1953, when he cut "Worried Blues" and "Lonesome World Blues." Despite the friendship between them, Love did not utilise Williamson's playing on any of his own material. In April 1953, Love and Williamson recorded in [[Houston]], [[Texas]], but it was Love's final recording session.{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/willie-love-mn0000959935/biography |title=Willie Love | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-02-01}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mnblues.com/cdreview/willielove3aces-cr.html |title=Willie Love & His Three Aces CD Review |publisher=Mnblues.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-01}} Love played piano on Williamson's albums, ''I Ain't Beggin' Nobody'' and ''Clownin' With The World'' (1953).[http://thebluescollective.blogspot.com/search/label/Willie%20Love ]{{dead link|date=February 2014}} All of Love's own recordings appeared on the [[compilation album]], ''Greenville Smokin''', issued in 2000. After suffering the effects of years of heavy drinking, Love died of [[bronchopneumonia]], in August 1953, at the age of 46. He was interred at the Elmwood Cemetery in [[Jackson, Mississippi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=13734473 |title=Willie Love (1906 - 1953) - Find A Grave Memorial |publisher=Findagrave.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-01}} ==Discography== ===Compilation albums=== *''Delta Blues : 1951'' (1990) *''Trumpet Masters, Vol. 1: Lonesome World Blues'' (1991) *''Greenville Smokin''' (2000) *''Shout Brother Shout''{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/willie-love-mn0000959935/discography/compilations |title=Willie Love | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-02-01}} ==See also== *[[List of Delta blues musicians]] *[[KWEM Radio]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.wirz.de/music/lovewfrm.htm Illustrated discography at Wirz.de] *{{Worldcat id|lccn-n95-9279}} {{Authority control|VIAF=32183872}} {{Persondata | NAME = Love, Willie | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Delta blues]] [[pianist]] | DATE OF BIRTH = November 4, 1906 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Duncan, Mississippi]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = August 19, 1953 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Jackson, Mississippi]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Love, Willie}} [[Category:1906 births]] [[Category:1953 deaths]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues pianists]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Mississippi]] [[Category:Musicians from Mississippi]] [[Category:Delta blues musicians]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]]
